abstract_summ: On another large dataset of [Formula: see text]281K instances corresponding to [Formula: see text]30K queries from diverse domains, our distilled 174 MB model provides an NDCG@1 of 75.08 with a CPU runtime of mere 31 ms establishing a new state-of-the-art for FAQ answering.The most common questions in our dataset asked about transmission, prevention, and societal effects of COVID, and we found that many questions that appeared in multiple sources were not answered by any FAQ websites of reputable organizations such as the CDC and FDA.Specifically, to the best of our knowledge, none of the existing Question Answering datasets provide any verbalization data for the question-query pairs.In this paper, we address an extractive summarization (i.e., headline extraction) task for such questions as a case study and consider how to alleviate the problem by using question-answer pairs, instead of missing-headline pairs.We present novel generation models for learning and suggesting lemma names for Coq projects.
title_summ: Distant Supervision for Extractive Question SummarizationANTIQUE: A Non-factoid Question Answering BenchmarkSemi-supervised Extractive Question Summarization Using Question-Answer PairsOptimized Transformer Models for FAQ AnsweringVQuAnDa: Verbalization QUestion ANswering DAtasetExploring NLP and Information Extraction to Jointly Address Question Generation and AnsweringENIGMA Anonymous: Symbol-IndependentInference Guiding Machine (System Description)Deep Generation of Coq Lemma Names Using Elaborated TermsWhat Are People Asking About COVID-19?A Question Classification Dataset
title_abstract_phrases: VQuAnDa: Verbalization QUestion ANswering DAtasetQuestion Answering (QA) systems over Knowledge Graphs (KGs) aim to provide a concise answer to a given natural language question.The most common questions in our dataset asked about transmission, prevention, and societal effects of COVID, and we found that many questions that appeared in multiple sources were not answered by any FAQ websites of reputable organizations such as the CDC and FDA.In this paper, we address an extractive summarization (i.e., headline extraction) task for such questions as a case study and consider how to alleviate the problem by using question-answer pairs, instead of missing-headline pairs.Specifically, to the best of our knowledge, none of the existing Question Answering datasets provide any verbalization data for the question-query pairs.The questions were asked by real users in a community question answering service, i.e., Yahoo!
